text: The following is shot DOCUMENTARY-STYLE. A GIRLS VOLLEYBALL GAME has just ended. It was a big game championship. ONE TEAM is CELEBRATING -- jumping up and down, squealing hugging each other. We are focused on the bench of the TE LOST. They're very sad -- several are crying. One girl, in particular, (AMY) is really sobbing. She's s stained, tired and just blubbering. Stuff's coming out of her nose, her mouth and the camera is seeing it all. The COACH, a fortyish man looks at all the weeping girls particular.
You quit! You gave up!
He KICKS a CHAIR. Now Amy is really a mess. She's crying, coughing, shaking
(right in Amy's face) You quit!!
The Coach storms off.
Qutters! ... Quitters!
Amy is wailing and choking on her own tears. This IMAGE FREEZES.
And that would be it. I don't think you need any narration at all. Just end it right there.

We're in New York City. We're in the conference room of a successful cable TV station called "Real TV." The people young, energetic, clever. It's crowded, noisy -the furnit beaten up, bulletin boards cover the walls, with large in all over them. This room is not for show -- work gets done here. SEVEN OR EIGHT PEOPLE are present. One of them is CYNTHIA She's the boss.
(to Cynthia) What do you think?
It's horrible, it's depressing, I love it. What else?
I want to re-pitch that pregnancy idea. Find six women early in their pregnancies and follow them all right through to the births.
(negative) Yeah, when all that stuff comes out.
Mixed reactions, mostly negative.
I have an idea.
This is something I've been thinking about for a long time. We're "Real TV" right? I mean that's the name of the station.
So let's go real. We find someone. Just a regular person, someone. And we put their life on television - live... all day long.
Silence. No movement at all.
Calm down.
What do you mean, like PBS did in the seventies? What was that family?
The Louds.
Yeah.

No. We go way beyond that. We don't film it and edit it and put it on later. We go on the air live every morning and the show goes off each night, when our subject goes to bed. In between, we're on live all day, every day - the same person, -- for (shrugs) let's say a month.
No one is wild for this. Some hate it -- some are unconvi
That's not a show that's a surveillance camera.
You can't do that.

The hell we can't. Look, the beauty of being a cable  channel is we can take chances. I've thought about this and I'm telling you, I think this can make a noise. A loud one. There are twelve thousand channels. You've got to do something that says "Look at me!" Hell, people look at fish tanks all day. This is people! (more firmly) Someone's real life -- an TV, all day long - live... And, you know what? I'm doing it.
Pause. The others know the argument is over.
In that case, we love it.
A BUS passes. On the bus is an ad. It says, "Would you like to star in your own TV show? Call Real TV (and a phone number) Coming (and a date)."

This is a nice upscale pool hall. A party is in progress special private area -- a room upstairs let's say -- a lo Thirty or forty PEOPLE in their twenties and thirties are informally celebrating the engagement of two of their fri It's NOISY, it's fun, it's informal. It's not a high-end By that we mean, not, for the most part young lawyers or stockbrokers. They're mostly blue-collar. Community colle graduates. WE OPEN ON ED PEKURNY. He's an attractive man, about thir There's still something a little juvenile about him -- no stupid, just boyish. SOMEONE is VIDEOTAPING HIM for one of those congratulatio montage things that are done at parties these days. Ed is at this. He's not professional but he's a loosey-goosey g who's kind of good on camera.
I want to congratulate Kevin and Tracy on their engagement. I knew you guys were meant for each other from the moment Tracy told us she was pregnant.
You asshole!
Everyone else is cracking up.
(innocently) What? What did I say?
My mother's going to see this!
Other people are being "interviewed" on tape. Ed is SHOOT with his buddy, JOHN. John's had a couple of drinks. He's melancholy. He is looking across the room, thoughtfully.
What?
Look at this -- people are getting married, they're getting married...
You said that.
We're falling behind.
Ed waves dismissively.
You know who we are?
Tell me.
We're the guys who clean up after the parade.
I'm gonna stick this right in your eye.

I was at this comedy club last week and this comedian says "If you're over thirty and your job requires you to wear a name tag, you screwed up your life." And I'm laughing and then I realize I wear a nametag.
So do I. So what? I'm doing all right.
Your brother's here.
Ed's brother RAY and Ray's girlfriend SHARI arrive at the Shari is pretty in an unglamorous kind of way. They both then Shari goes off to talk to some of the LADIES and Ray and John.
What's up?
Where were you?
(reluctantly) I was... having dinner with Shari and her parents.
(taunting) Oooh!
I'm telling you, it's closing in on me. All of a sudden it's like a thing, it's a whole thing.
What do you mean all of a sudden? You've been going with her six months.

I know. I mean I'm sitting there and her father's asking me about my "career prospects" and I'm playing "Risk," with her kid brother, Leon and at dinner the dog's sniffing at my balls -- at least I hope it was the dog. 'Cause her mother disappeared for a while.
They LAUGH.
It's getting wild. Some of the girls are dancing raucousl

head_text.subj: A TABLE, (NOT A POOL TABLE, AN EATING-TABLE)

text: Ed, Ray, John, Shari and maybe another WOMAN. Ray is holding a big tray of SHRIMP BALLS. During the conversation, Ray throws them in the air and catches them his mouth like popcorn. Once, he even bounces one off the wall into his mouth.
You know, those are for everybody.
Ray waves dismissively, then gets an idea.
Oh! (to Shari) Show them that thing you can do. (to the others) This is great. I just found out she can do this, her brother told me. (to Shari) Come on.
(thinks it's stupid) I don't -
Come on...
She hesitates, but she really doesn't mind. Slightly, amu takes her FIST and fits it completely INTO her MOUTH.
Whoa!! Oh!
Ray is cracking up.
Is that unbelievable?
She removes her hand.
And that concludes today's show. (to Ray) This is where you go around and collect the money.
Ed LAUGHS. Ray gives her a KISS. Shari's roommate RITA sits down.
Hi.
You guys know my roommate, Rita.
They do, vaguely.
What's going on over there?
Everybody's making audition tapes for that Real TV thing.
Oh, that thing. Yeah. Did you hear about this?
(not sure) Yeah, what - they put some schmuck on TV all day long or something?
You know, that would be like a great thing.
What?
That! Being that guy. Being the guy they watch.
What are you drunk?
Yeah, but let's stay on one subject. Whoever that person is is going to be famous. They'll be able to get whatever they want. They'll ... trust me, this is my business.
What is?!
Show business.
You're in show business?
Yeah. I service video equipment.
That's like... those people stitching Nikes in Panama saying they're in the NBA.
(insulted) I'm not stitching Nikes in Panama! ... Bedwetter!
Thumbsucker!
I'm making a tape.
We're excited.
Ed and Shari, waiting for drink orders.
So Ray met the family.
Yeah...
I hear the dog really liked him.
Oh, the whole family loved him. Of course, they loved the last guy I went out with, and he strung me along for three years and dumped me.
Really? You see, to me, you shouldn't have any trouble with men. There should be, like, a line behind you.
She takes Ed's beer.
You shouldn't drink.
They LAUGH.
Ed and Shari ARM-WRESTLING. After a struggle, Ed wins. Ed impressed.
Jesus!
Shari wrings out her arm and picks up her beer.

(continuing a previous conversation) And, you know, every guy I ever broke up with, the minute it was over, I could tell you what went wrong, how it went wrong, why it had to go wrong... but when I'm in it... lost. I'm like a love coroner. Bring me the corpse, I'11 tell you what killed it. But how to prevent it? Lost.
Ed LAUGHS.
Ray's on.
They walk over.
(to camera) Hi. I'm Ray Pekurney. I'm from Paramus, New Jersey...
She's watching Ray's tape. Ray thinks he's funnier and cuter than he is.
All my friends tell me "Ray, you've got too much personality for one guy." It's like at a party -- I'm at the center of the attention. Everybody loves me.
He gets hit in the face by a hors d'oeuvre.
Ha, ha, ha. I'll kick your ass. No really, let me show you my girlfriend. She's really cute.
He reaches out and grabs Shari's wrist. Shari is struggli to stay out of frame. We just see her arm and Ray pulling it. Ray lets go.
She's strong, 'cause she's a Fedex girl. She lifts those packages. But she's not dikey at all, she's really pretty.
WE SEE the camera shooting an empty space. Then Ed's head appears sideways right in front of the CAM
Hello I'm Ed.
He starts to sniff.
What smells?
He steps back from the camera and straightens his head as he SNIFFS. He's more relaxed than Ray.
What is that smell? Oop, I think it's this idea. One person on TV all day long? (screams) Are you nuts?
The Real TV Staff are enjoying Ed's tape while they eat lunch out of styrofoam containers.

Seriously, get your resumes in order. When my brother Ray - whose personality you were just dazzled by -- told me he was going to try out for this -- I said, "why in the world would anyone want to be on TV all day long, no privacy, everybody knowing your business, exposing every single detail of your life I mean... why would anyone want to do that? But then I thought of a reason... (loudly) Why the hell not?
He KISSES the LENS, smudging it. Cynthia, watching, cracks up. The others seem to like him

This is a video store in Paramus, New Jersey. It's busy. PEOPLE are in line to check out tapes. WE OPEN ON a WOMAN -- a mother -- who is rummaging throug purse for her Blockbuster card. She looks up and sees tha TWO CHILDREN have opened several boxes of candy from the display and are eating from the boxes.
Oh for -- Put those -- Oh God...
She grabs the boxes from them. The boxes are ripped more thought and candy goes flying all over. She bends to pick Ed appears. He works here.
(to the Mom) We'11 take care of it.
Someone arrives with a broom.
(to the broom guy) Here. This time throw it out, don't eat it.
LOU, the Manager passes.
Lou, can I talk to you a second?
Lou seems like he'd prefer to avoid this.
Um, yeah, I was gonna ...
What's the deal? Did anybody make a decision -
Ed, look, uh... you're not getting the job. They're gonna transfer someone from another store to manage this store when I leave to manage the new store. I'm sorry.
Oh, Christ. Did you go to bat for me?
I batted!
You batted or you bunted?

Hey. I went as far as I felt comfortable. I mean, you know, let's face it -- you come and go here as you please. You work when you feel like it -- you know, Bruce Springsteen's birthday is not a legal holiday.
Well, then I'm quitting.
Ed, come on. What's that gonna do? You're gonna bring Blockbuster to their knees. Let me recommend a movie to you. It's called "Get your shit together before it's too late."
(wise-ass) Who's in it?
Ed, telephone.
Ed goes to the phone.
(into the phone) Yeah... Are you serious? ... Come on, no kidding, who is this? ... Holy shit!
Ed is being interviewed by the "Real TV" staff whom we me He's slightly less comfortable than on his tape, but he's
I had one year of college. And then one year of junior college.
What did you study?
Oh, see, studying would've been a huge help. Where were you, then?
They LAUGH.

Well, there's Ray, my brother. He's... ambitious. Like a few years ago, he started this mobile dog-grooming business. But, like, out of his Camry. He had this bathtub in his trunk - (Ed starts cracking up) he's throwing the dogs in there, they're fighting and splashing, then he'd slam the trunk down, let 'em run around inside screaming getting all wet... then he'd use the car exhaust to dry'em. (wiping his eyes) Ah, Ray... he just can't get a break.

My sister -- Marcia, I mean she can't get a break. About seven years ago she falls in love with this Vietnamese guy who wants to marry her so he can stay in the country. So they get married, they have a kid, he gets his citizenship, immediately divorces my sister and marries this Vietnamese woman who, he was probably already married to all along. She can pick 'em. (pause) She's got a nice little boy, though. My nephew, Andy.
My Mom's okay. Kinda. I knew a guy who hated his mother - Stuey Shwam. He hated his mother so much, he had his belly button removed.
No, I've never been married.
The interviewer seems to be waiting for him to elaborate. He doesn't. He shrugs -- that's it.
Oh, my father -what an asshole. When I was twelve, my mother needed a hysterectomy -- my father ran off with her nurse! And that's the last I heard of him.
Al, my stepfather he's opinionated. And you have to listen because he's like in a wheelchair.

I like my job -- I mean I'm doing all right. I'm not sure how long I want to stay there, you know... I mean, I'm thirty-one... I'm not sure I want to be a video store clerk when I'm forty... Of course, I didn't expect to be doing it 'til I was thirty-one, either. But... you know I'm... keeping my options open. Anything comes along, I'm ready to pounce. (growls like a cougar)
A dream? Of course I have a dream I just don't know what the hell it is. (shrugs and smiles)

Ed's image freezes, while he has a funny-cute expression his face. PULL BACK TO REVEAL a TV in a conference room with Ed's frozen image on it. Cynthia is there with her bosses, the people who run the network that owns Real TV. The top man MR. SCHARLACH. His deputies are MS. SEAVER and MR. McILVA This is not the same place where we met Cynthia and her staff. This is richer, more corporate and formal.
He's who we want to go with.
(doubtfully) This guy.
I polled my staff. The men say they'd hang around with him and the women say he's fuckable. And one of the men said he's fuckable.
I'm not sure about the entire concept.
Cynthia is frustrated.

Look it's not like we're  burning up the airwaves now. We're running neck-and-neck with The Gardening Channel. If people just tune in to this twice a day for five minutes, we're a hit. Plus we can sell advertising every second, running at the bottom of the screen... and the beauty is this guy doesn't even have to be good. I mean if he's good, great. But if he winds up making an ass of himself, better. McILVAINE How is that better?

Come on. People cannot turn away from an accident. You drive by, you say "Ooh, I hope there's not a head lying in the road" but you look ! See, nobody in America wants to be nobody. This guy wants to be famous. So, basically, the deal is he agrees to drive down the highway a hundred miles an hour blindfolded and we get to see if his head winds up rolling down the highway. Fun for the whole family. So let's do it.
She stops, waiting for approval.
(coldly) Good luck.
Ed's RE-STOCKING the SHELVES He gets goosed from behind
(very loud and happy) Hey...
(goosed) Oh!
Ed DROPS the BOXES. Ray is there with Shari.
I got your message. Way to go!
Hi, Shari. (to Ray) Let's go in the stockroom.
Ed and Ray enter.
So when do you start?
I ... I'm not gonna do it.
What?
Look -- there's a million ways to humiliate yourself - I gotta think of a new way? I mean, it's all day! Every minute. Id be like a monkey at the zoo. I just...
(disgusted) Oh man! They couldn't pick me! They had to pick you!
He slaps a tape off a shelf.
You would do this? You would actually --
In a second! In a hot second. Let me ask you something --
Why do you do that?
What?
Whenever you ask me something why do you always say "Let me ask you something?" Why don't you just ask me?
(impatiently) All right. Let me ask you something... are you happy like this?
I'm doing all right.
Oh Yeah? What's your master plan here?
Shari enters, curious about the yelling. She stands there quietly, unnoticed by the guys.
You're gonna be a video store clerk for the rest of your life? This is your big ambition, rearranging the "Ernest" movies?
Screw off.
How many opportunities are you going to get in your life?
I don't know.
That's right. You don't know. Doors don't fly open for guys like us.
Hey. You know-- we're not the same. I got a good life, this job suits me. I come and go when I please --
Oh, don't bullshit a bullshitter. If you're happy like this you're an idiot, and you're not an idiot. (sees Shari) Hi.
Ed turns and sees Shari. She's self-conscious. She feels been caught eavesdropping.
Oh. I -- I heard Ray yelling. 1 didn't mean to --

(to Ed) Give me a chance. I'm begging you. I need a break. Look, I'11 cover your ass. I'11 ride shotgun. Just bring those cameras over to me and I'11 make something happen for both of us. I swear. Come on, Eddie
Pause.
All right.
Yeah?!
Yeah.
Ray lifts Ed up. Ray kisses Ed.
(to Shari) Is this guy a brother?!
Moderate-priced, restaurant. WE OPEN ON a CLOSE-UP of AL. He's about seventy.
What happens when you go to the bathroom? Do they go in with you?

Ed, Ray, Al, JEANETTE and MARCIA. Al is in a WHEELCHAIR a oxygen mask connected to a tank. He periodically takes a oxygen. He's a little short of breath, but loves to talk. is Ed's mother -- about sixty. Marcia is a little older t
No. The bathroom is off limits -and when I go to sleep they go to other programming. Unless I get up. Then they go back on the air. Unless I get up to go to the bathroom, I guess, then -
What if--you're vomiting?
(amazed by the question) What if I'm vomiting?
Do they show it?
I guess -- I don't -- it's all in the contract. There's this million-page contract --
Look, can we all just sign the releases so we can get on with this?
(accusing, to Ed) What happened? You described this "crazy-kooky" family who'd be a million laughs on TV?
No! I barely even mentioned -it's just that, my friends, the people at work, whoever I'm regularly in contact with they want releases from.
(angrily) They're gonna mock our foibles.
Our what?
Our foibles, our foibles!
We don't have foibles.
Everyone has foibles. Then the whole country sees them on TV and mocks them. Then we have... mocked foibles.
Eddie, please don't let them mock our foibles.
(losing it) Stop saying foibles!
Look, my life is not so great, that I want it shown on television. And neither is yours.
That's the point -- this could change things.
How?
For instance... me and my friend Bucky are buying out my boss. His equipment, trucks, client list, the whole shmear.
(points to Ed) What does that have to do with... ?
If they keep Ed on for one full month, he gets a balloon payment.
Ed nods. Pause.
I borrow  against that now, at the bank. Buy the business. And Ed becomes a silent partner. Now here's the beauty part. While we're on TV I plug the shit out of the business. Free advertising.
How about sex?
A STUNNED pause. They all look at Al.
I'11 have to pass, Al. And it's not an age thing --
No! Do they show you having sex?
No. Kissing and hugging, okay, but if it's actual sex they have to cut away.
At what point?
At the point -- I don't -- Look you'd be on TV maybe one or two times each. I'11 try to avoid I'11 go out of my way to avoid, getting together with you. Believe me.
WE HEAR: A loud drilling sound.

A WORKMAN is drilling a hole in the wall. Ed is there with a TV CREW. They're running cable and dri examining the apartment. Cynthia is going around supervising. Ray and Shari are th fascinated. Ed is tense. Shari is observant. Ray separate and Shari and asks one of the Installers a technical ques
Ed thinks. Ed joins Cynthia.
Are you sure about this?
Hey, believe me -1 know I've got a great chance of making a fool of myself, here.
Why do it?
I saw this show once. It was about logging. I was home sick, there was nothing else on. Do you know how they break up really bad log jams? You know, when they're really tangled... ?
Cream rinse?
(laughs)  Dynamite.
So?
So maybe this is my dynamite.
Dynamite is dangerous.
Ed, can I see you a second.
(to Shari) Excuse me.
Okay, so you understand? We're installing a permanent camera in your bedroom, one in the kitchen, one in the living room, plus, of course, there'll always be a couple of steady-cams following you.
(overwhelmed) Cool.
I want you to take this.
She gives him a card.
That has my work number, my home number, my pager number. I sleep three hours a night. Call me whenever you want to talk. Off the air, on the air, whenever. Okay?
(barely listening) Um, yeah -- thanks.
Ed looks kind of overwhelmed. She doesn't like this.
Now look. Don't freeze up on me. I picked you because you had kind of a relaxed, go-with-the-flow quality. You're not going to lose that, are you?
No, uh...
I bet my career on you. You'd better be good.
(annoyed) Don't say that. That's like... telling a guy before you have sex you'd better be good. You don't do that.
I do.
Ed reacts.
Oh.
He's in bed, watching TV. The news is on. He glances up a the cameras. On the news, they go to a story about him.

Tomorrow morning, the cable  channel known as Real TV, begins broadcasting one of the most heavily promoted concepts in the history of cable television. In an experiment that they say will last at least a month. They're going to follow -- live - every waking minute of a thirty-one year old video store clerk from Paramus New Jersey. The Real TV press release on this promises that none of it will be scripted, none of it will be edited and in my opinion, none of it will be interesting. we're all just supposed to sit in front of our TV's and watch this guy... live. (rhymes with "give")
(to the Entertainment Reporter) What would be the interest here? What would... get people to tune in?
Betas me.
I don't know. I might check it out.
Well, Len's here to check out sports. Len, would you watch this video clerk?
I'd sooner watch soccer.
They all CRUCKLE.
She's watching the same show. She's edgy. She's CRACKING her KNUCKLES.
Speaking of disasters, at the Meadowlands tonight...
The set goes off. Ed, once again, stares up at the camera
Written on the screen -- "Day one." A DIRECTOR and TECHNICAL CREW with all the modern equipme
Here we go. Ten-nine-eight-seven-
Cynthia and her staff are gathered to watch the show begi They're TENSE and EXCITED. A commercial is on.
two... one.
On the TV, the commercial ends and the Real TV logo appea

It says "The following is unedited, unscripted, and unreh is the real life of one American citizen named Ed Pekurny The logo fades away and we see Ed, in bed, sleeping. His and he wakes up. He's groggy from sleep. Instinctively, he begins SCRATCHI balls. As he does, it hits him that this is not a normal  morning. He looks up and sees two steady-cam guys at the bed, aiming their cameras at him. Ed, then, looks at his balls. Gently, he moves his hand away.
(mock cheerful) Well, we're off to a great start.
NOTE: The camera operators will change in shifts. We'11 s about four regulars over the course of the film. The one will see most often is shooting Ed right now. His name is CARLOS.
Ed, wearing shorts and a T-shirt, gets out of bed. His ha sticking up. He passes a mirror and notices his hair.
Oh, great.
He turns to the camera and seems about to offer an excuse for his appearance, but, then, just moves on.
Excuse me.
He grabs some clothes and enters the bathroom.
They're not enjoying this. Everyone's staring at Cynthia. doesn't flinch. NOTE: Silent advertising runs along the bottom of the scr

Ed enters, dressed and showered. The Steady-cam is in his face. Ed is tight. He's much less comfortable than he expected be. He smiles stiffly at the camera. He's misplaced his natural charm. He gets a box of Pop-tarts out of the freezer. As he does other stuff falls out of the freezer on to the floor. He' embarrassed. He bends down to pick things up, showing his to the camera.
(to Cynthia) Start clearing a place for your Emmy.
Ed is sitting up on the kitchen counter eating his Pop-ta a bowl of cereal.
(nervously) Same people like to put the milk in first and then the cereal. I like to put in the milk first - I mean the cereal first and then the milk. Yeah, that's it. Now, watch this.
He takes a KNIFE and a BANANA. He peels the banana. He ho knife, blade up, over the cereal and chops down on it wit banana, several times, rapidly, slicing it into the cerea proud of this.
Ray is watching the show. His head is in his hands. He's horrified by how bad Ed is.
Jeanette and Al watching Ed.
(being positive) So far...
Somebody shoot me.
Scharlach, Seaver and McIlvaine watching, grim-faced.
Cynthia is ON the PHONE.
Get him out of the house! I want him moving!
(on the phone) Hey, I want him dead, but what can I do.
Ed is EATING. He peers confused at the camera.
CAMERA OPERATORS. They're signaling Ed to get out.
Bewildered, imitating their gestures.
What... You want me to swim?
The Director is still on the phone. She's watching Ed on monitor.
Oh God...
Ed gets it.
Oh, out? You want me to go out.

Ed exits the building with the Operators walking backward of him, bumping into PEOPLE- People watch, curiously. Ed reaches his car. He takes out his keys and drops them puddle. Disgusted, he fishes them out.
Scharlach, watching impassively.

Ed, in the car. He can barely fit the key into the igniti in the passenger seat taps him on the arm. Ed looks up. C up a hastily-made sign. "It's okay. Relax, man." Carlos W does help Ed. He appreciates it. He drives. WE SEE the control truck in motion. We also see another c with another Steady-cam OPERATOR, shooting Ed's car as th travel.

Ed is doing his morning errands. A little shopping -- a l banking -- always ON CAMERA. At one point, he WALKS INTO GLASS DOOR with the word "Pull" on it. He pushed,  banging his forehead. A CHILD points to the word "Pull." to the camera, embarrassed. Later he buys a slice of pizz little place that's doing no business.
(to the camera) Best pizza in New Jersey.

As he walks down the street, PEOPLE call out "Hey Ed!" Pe in windows show him that they're watching him at that exa moment. The camera shoots some of the people in the windows. They themselves on TV and they go wild. Ed also is confronted GUYS grabbing their crotches mockingly, calling out thing like "Hey, Ed, holding your own?" or "Hey, Ed, howls the ballroom." Ed is slightly chagrined by all this, but hand it with good grace. He seems to be loosening up.

Ed arrives at work. The store is already open. (Ed usuall gets there in the afternoon and stays until closing.) CUSTOMERS are a little stunned by the arrival of a camera Some know what it's about some don't. The CLERKS are aware of what's going on. They all signed releases. Ed's BOSS greets him stiffly. Clearly he's tryi to get face-time on camera.
Hey, Lou.
(stiffly) Welcome to work, Ed.

He shakes Ed's hand and smiles at the camera. He WAVES a The BROOM GUY crosses, staring transfixed at the camera. blocks Ed and Lou. He FREEZES, then panics. He tries to g out of the way and trips over his broom. He tumbles face- into the camera lens, hurting himself. ANGLE ON ED, observing.
(mutters) Oh, Jesus, I'm dying.

Carlos, give him some air, give him some room. Use a longer lens. We'11 mostly go with the stationary cameras in here. Less intrusive. (to the crew in the truck, sarcastically) Have any of you thought about your next career?
A WOMAN is serving dinner. She's watching Ed on TV -- rea glancing at it. Her HUSBAND is helping her bring the food table.
Why are we watching this?
(a little guilty) No reason. just... I just want to see what happens.
Nothing's gonna happen. He's just... working.
Oh, come on, they wouldn't put it on if nothing was gonna happen.

He changes the channel. She changes it back. He doesn't g at all. RAPID CUTS of VARIOUS PEOPLE around America, watching -- young guy, a woman alone -- ending with a few college-age appears to be a dorm room. ONE GIRL is watching intently. Her roommates are mostly j hanging around not really watching.
I think he's cute.

Ed and Shari get up to leave. They look at each other, ve affectionately. They want to kiss. The cameras are close. Ed is wearing a jacket. He spreads it out wide to block Shari's face from the cameras. He leans in and they KISS the lips, several times, while Ed's jacket screens off th cameras. They're in love.

head_text.subj: INT. TV NEWS SHOW- THREE WEEKS LATER

text: Written on the screen -- "Day 26." It's the same news team we met earlier.
Well, welve had pet rocks, hula hoops, Davy Crockett, Beatle wigs, and leisure suits. But America's latest craze is a guy named Ed. Here with that story is entertainment reporter, Rick Douglas.

Pat, four weeks ago, no one in America had even heard of Ed Pekurny. Today, this thirty-one year-old video store clerk has become something of a national obsession. The words viewers use to describe him are "charming," "natural," and "appealing." And ratings indicate that "Ed TV" is being watched by more people, each day, than any show in the history of cable television.
A SHOT of Scharlach being interviewed. A CAPTION identifi
This idea just came to me. I told my staff -- if people just tune in twice a day for five minutes we're a hit. Sometimes you gotta go with your gut feeling.
She's watching. She's ANGRY.
Sure it came to you! Because I brought it to you! (raises her fist) You want a gut feeling?! How about a groin feeling?! (raises her foot)

Ed TV has become so popular that when Ed goes to sleep Real TV is running highlights of Ed's day all night. Some viewers have become obsessed with Ed. They wake up when Ed wakes up, they go to sleep when Ed goes to sleep, and in between they try to watch as much of him as possible.
(casually) Yeah, I watch it... More than I'd like to admit sometimes.
(about fifty) Never... no...
Honestly? ... I try not to go to the bathroom until Ed goes to the bathroom so I won't miss anything.
A GUY in an ice cream store.
Watch this! Like Ed.
He slices a banana the way Ed does.
I just kind of leave it an, you know, so it's... there.
TEEN-AGER #l I don't like Shari. She's ... needy.
I like her. She's sweet.
She just rubs me the wrong way.
I'm so glad they got rid of Ray. He was creepy.
To me, this Shari is like nothing.
She's not even hot. I mean Ed's a celebrity. If that was me, I'd be dating the goods.
There's something wrong with her. She's definitely not hot.
Not hot. Not.
She's watching this, wearing a bathrobe. Her self-esteem is being crushed.
This is an "E TV" kind of gossip show. The host -- a YOUN WOMAN -- is showing film of Ed and Shari getting out of E car. The film freeze-frames. Shari has an  unflattering look on her face.
What's wrong with her! Everytime you look at this chick, it's like she badly needs a Tampax. Ed, you can do better.
Shari watching, in horror.
Ed and Shari are on a date. A WAITRESS is taking their or Shari still seems a little self-conscious, but Ed is havi ball.
I'11 have... (to Shari) Get this -- (to the waitress) I'11 have the "Ed."
I'm stunned.
A WOMAN with her young SON approach.
Mr. Pekurny. I'm sorry to bother you. My son would just love to have your autograph.
No problema. (to the boy) You want a picture?
The boy nods.
Moe.
MOE, the Bodyguard, in the next booth hands Ed a glossy o and a pen. Ed signs it.
Take this around the corner to Frame World, they'll give you a discount.
The Woman and Child leave.
(to Shari) Oh -- Sunday is good for me to meet your folks. We get a big family audience on Sundays so it works out.
(ironic) That's lucky.
Saturday, I think we should
Ed takes a phone out of his pocket.

(plugging) Compliments of Motorola. Hello... Marcia?? (to Shari) My sister. -- What? ... What, right now? ... I'm eating, I'm on a date! ... Well, where's your boyfriend -- what's his name? Cliff .... Then, call a cab... (wearily) All right. Look, just don't start any trouble okay. Just sit there quietly 'til I get there... you're welcome.
He HANGS UP. He's disgusted.

This used to be a regular thing. And the worst part, is while she'd be waiting for me to come down to some bar and get her, she'd start up with some guy and say "Wait 'til my brother gets here, he'11 kick your ass." So then I walk in and there's some rhinoceros in a windbreaker who tries to shove me into a shot glass. And Marcia's drunk and screaming "Kick his ass, Ed. Kick his ass." (looks out) I think this is it.
It's not a seedy dive. Ed and Shari and the camera operat enter. A CUSTOMER approaches.
Hey, hey, hey, hey, hey. You're the guy on TV.
What was the tip-off? The enormous camera?
Watch this.
The guy does Ed's "Happy Dance."
See, like you.
Yeah. Keep up the good work.
Ed brushes by him. He sees a WOMAN passed out at a table.
Oh great.
He prepares to lift her.
Ed.
He turns and sees Marcia standing there.
What are you doing?
Hm? I'm, uh... Why isn't this drunken woman you?
He lets go of the woman. Her head bounces on the table.
What's going on? Why did you want me to come down here?
Marcia guides them into chairs.
Cliff is here. He's performing. I wanted you to see him.
For a second, Ed doesn't get it. Then.
Oh! Oh -- okay, now I get it. It's "Star Search." You wanted me here because the camera comes with me.
Ed, he needs a break. You don't know what kind of bad luck he's had --
I can imagine. You said you wanted nothing to do with this. You swore to me. "Don't come near me. Don't bring this into my life..."
For God sakes, you said two words about some lousy pizza joint, the guy's a millionaire now. This could be my whole future we're talking about. (to Shari) Hi, I'm Ed's sister.
(politely) I've heard so much about you.

Cliff is in the middle of his show. He's wearing a PORTABLE ORGAN. He's not great. He's a sma professional with a lot of pep. Marcia is beaming. Ed's cameras are shooting him. CUTS OF Cliff, singing every type of song, imaginable. Th guy is desperately trying to cover all the bases -- i.e. Sinatra-type standards, something from "Lion King", "Do Y Think I'm Sexy," "Smokin' in the Boy's Room," "Hey, Hey, the Monkees," the theme from "Hawaii Five-0," a rap numbe "Ave Maria."
(sotto) I wish my stepfather was here.
Why?
He could give me some oxygen.
Ed and Shari are KISSING.
Oh boy! Here we go!
Ed is passionate.
(cringing) Euuw...
Fuming.
Um...
What?
She indicates the camera. Ed tries to allay her fears.
I told you. If we... you know do it, they go away until ... we're done.
I know, but even if they go away, everybody in America knows what we're doing because... they went away.
So? What do they think -- we're not kids --
(overlapping) I know, I ...
(overlapping) Shari, I really like you...
(overlapping) I really like you too...
...if this ... (the camera) ... weren't here... ?
... yeah, then, but...
Ed... I think we should stop seeing each other.
The guys who said she wasn't hot. They applaud.
They're booing Shari.
A very attractive woman (JILL) and her friend.
That girl's an idiot.
What?... Why?
(starting to weep) I can't take it anymore...

head_text.subj: GUYS WHO DON'T THINK SHE'S HOT

text: They mock her, crying "Boo hoo hoo" and pretending to rub eyes.
(crying) I have no privacy. Even now! I'm crying and I can't stop and they won't go away. And now it's going to be another month!
Shari...
Everybody hates me!
No. Who?
Look at this.
She picks up a N.Y. POST.
Page three of the Post.
(knows what it is) Ohh...
A poll. "Is Shari Good Enough for Ed?" Seventy-one per cent said "no." (crying) They hate me!
Who cares? I don't ca -- No. I do care. (to the camera) Shame on everybody. Shame on you! Well, just the seventy-one percent. The other... (he can't do the math)
Twenty-nine.

Exactly. Boy, you're smart. (to the camera) Why are you so mean to her? What did she do to you? (picks up newspaper) "Is she good enough for Ed?" Who the hell am I? (sarcastically) Who the hell do you think I should be dating?
There's a list.
Really? (he looks)
Ed?
He doesn't hear her. He's scanning the list.
Wow...
Ed is a guest.
I'm out here an hour a night and I feel like a dork. You're on every minute! Doesn't it just drive you nuts?
(cheerfully) Yeah.
All this fame and the money you're making. Is this going to change you, do you think?
God, I hope so.
It's after the show. Ed is getting ready to leave. John i with him, keeping him company. A. P.A. is giving Ed a bag gifts. (Of course, Ed is still on Ed TV.)
You've got a ham in there and Dave's book and --
Hey, if it's free, it's me. (to John) You ready?
Yeah. You did good. What's wrong?
Aah, I wanted Shari to come.
Oh -- so I'm just, what -- a poor substitute?
He KISSES John.
(easily) Yeah. (to the camera) Honey, if you're watching this is for you.
No! Don't -- (new subject) Oh, wow.
What?
ANGLE ON JILL IN THE HALLWAY (We met her earlier in a cut She's saying good-bye to a CASTING ASSISTANT.
No more calls, we have a  winner.
Jill looks up, sees Ed and walks right up to him
Hi.
Hi.
SECURITY steps forward.
It's all right.
They step back.
I'm Jill. I really like your show. I think you're great.
Thanks... That's ...
Shari, watching this on television.
You must be John.
I'm trying to remember.
(to Ed) Well, I don't want to bother you, I'm just -- I was here auditioning for a skit. You know, one of those things where Dave goes around town with models and whatever...
Oh, yeah, I love those. Yeah... those are funny...
Well, it was really nice meeting you and, uh... (checks her watch) I'd better get a cab.
But she doesn't leave.
Um... They gave me a limo, uh...
Oh, great! Thanks. I'm just going uptown.
She takes his arm and leads him out.
Written on the screen -- "Day 28" Two WOMEN on Stairmasters.
V11 bet he goes out with her. It's like those actors -- as soon as they get famous -- Pfft - there goes the wife.
The dorm girls.
He'll never cheat on Shari!
The game includes Tad and Barry.
You think she really likes him?
She doesn't give a shit about him.
You know what would be great?
What?
If Ray would steal this girl from Ed. That would be great.
You know what would be even better?
What?
If you shut your hole and played cards. Goddam pineapple brothers.
The same eggheads who, earlier, had no interest in Ed. No they're all worked up.
But he's not a normal person anymore. He's a celebrity. We're no longer observing anyone's "real life."
(disagreeing) But that's what's interesting! The effect of celebrity on an otherwise average person.
But do you really feel that Ed is an average person? I mean this guy seems to have a... magnetism, a charisma that, I think, transcends the entire concept.
I agree. He's special.
They all nod.
Ed is opening letters and packages. There are piles of th
This is from a girl named Tawny... this goes in the nude picture pile. Thank you, Tawny.
He places it in a large pile. He opens another envelope.
Let's see.
Ed stares and his smile disappears.
A picture of Ed's face with his body drawn underneath it. body is spurting blood and is mutilated. Ed stares at it.
Well. This is creative. This goes in the psychopath pile.
The DOORBELL RINGS.
Oh, I hope that's not this guy. (indicates psycho letter)
He PICKS UP a baseball bat and crosses to the door. He opens the door. A handsome man in his early sixties is there. His name is HANK.
Hello.
Hi.
Ed waits.
You don't recognize me.
No. Am I supposed to?
Hank shrugs. Ed stares at him, then begins to look a litt shaken.
Jeanette is putting a jar in the refrigerator. She glance the television. She drops the jar. It SHATTERS...
Marcia is with her half-Asian son ANDY. She's serving his dinner. OFF-CAMERA we HEAR Cliff SINGING and the DOG HOWL in distress. Glancing at the television, Marcia gasps.
Ray is TYPING on a word processor. He stares curiously at the television.
Ed is staring at Hank doubtfully.
It's me, Hank -- your father.
RAPID CUTS of VIEWERS, excited. Many of them reach for th phone.
The Real TV staff react. Cynthia looks over-- stunned.
(to Cynthia) Did you do this? Did you find him and get him to--
No way... Oh, this just keeps getting better.

Written on the screen -- "Day 35" Ed and his mother are arguing. Al is sucking oxygen and h pile of "People" magazines with Ed on the cover. A REPAIR is fixing the refrigerator. All their food is out and mel Jeanette is trying to preserve food in an ice chest while argues with Ed.
I can't believe you're taking his side.
I'm not! I'm just trying to get some facts.
(to Ed) Sign this one to Nancy. She's the nurse who handles my urine.
Ed signs.
I told you the facts! He abandoned us -- those are the facts.
So everything he told me yesterday was a lie. Everything.
Al takes a loud breath.
Yes! ... practically
What do you mean practically? Did he really run away or did you throw him out like he says.
I need to replace the coil.
(to Ed) He ran away after I threw him out. (to repairman) How much is a new coil?
A hundred and fifty bucks.
So he was telling the truth you threw him out.
Should I go ahead?
Yes.
Yes to me or yes to the coil?
Both.
Holy sh--
This one to Dr. Bamajian. Maybe he won't make me wait an hour.
Ed signs.
He had girlfriends!
He says --
I don't care what he says. Look, I don't need to relive this. On television!
Whatever happened to Norman Rockwell?
Who?
Norman Rockwell. He painted magazine covers. Folksy. A mailman, a boy scout, a kid visiting a doctor...
Yeah, so... ?
They celebrated the common person.
Well, I don't think you can get more common than me, Al.
No. Only celebrities now. Now, if you put a mailman on the cover of a magazine he'd better have killed someone or no one will buy it. This one to Dr. Rumpley.
Jeanette storms back in.

All right -- do you want to know the truth? I took you and Marcia and Ray to my sister's on the train for the weekend and you all got chicken pox. So I took you home a day early and there was your father with a woman in our bed. Okay?
Chicken pox? I was six. He didn't leave 'til I was twelve.
He... apologized, he begged me. He can be very... charming when it suits his purpose.
But what was that whole story about him and a nurse?
She could've been a nurse.
Could've been a nurse?
She had white shoes.
So does Grandma. So does Shaquille O'Neal. You told me you had a hysterectomy and he ran off with your nurse.
What's the difference?
The difference is for twenty years I thought one thing and now it's another thing.
Ed nods.
He was no good. Do you remember how he used to scream at me? You used to cover your ears with dinner rolls.
Also, no job was ever good enough for him. "Small potatoes, small potatoes." Al, you remember --
Al breathes loudly.
Wait a minute. I thought you didn't know Al, 'til after Dad left.
Pause. Even the repairman pokes his head out of the refrigerator.
Oh my God. You and Al were - and that's why you threw him out.
He had a woman in my own bed! And how dare you call him "Dad" in front of Al. (shakes Al by the shoulder) This is your father. This is who was there for you when you needed someone.
Jeanette, you're hurting me.
(on the defensive) I'm not -- I didn't -- Al, you know how I feel about you...
Al breathes loudly.
(uncomfortably) If I don't call you "Dad" it' just because... 1 was already a big boy when you came into our lives -- (pointedly to his mother) or when I thought you came into our lives --
And what did he come back now for?
Who?

Hank! All of a sudden. Because now you're famous and he can get something from you. I don't wan you to become a victim like Marcia. (to the TV) Not that you're a victim, honey. You're not. Life's just been a little hard on you, sweetie.
(to Al) What do you think. I mean about... him. Should I just... have nothing to do with him? I mean...
(to Ed) Have I ever said a bad word to you about your father?
No.
Well, now I will. He was a crazy mean, son-of-a-bitch.
Al starts to wheel himself out. Ed looks weary.
But he was your father.
He's asleep.
They're monitoring him. They see Ed WAKE UP. They stir. Sleepy, and scratching his ass, he goes into the bathroom
Ed shuts the door. He takes his PORTABLE PHONE OUT of a bathroom drawer. (He stashed it there.) He makes a call a waits.
(whispering) Hi... it's me, Ed. It's been two days, I want to see you... No, I won't let them follow me, I'11 sneak out... No it's not allowed, but I'm going for it... I'm on my way.
He takes CLOTHING OUT of the bathroom hamper. until he finds something acceptable.
They're monitoring the empty bed.
Ed is dressed. He CLIMBS OUT his bathroom window.
Shari opens her front door.
Hi.
She looks down the hallway.
They're not here.
He goes in, grabs her and kisses her passionately.
I tried to tell you over the phone -- my parents went to Atlantic City.
So?
So my little brother's staying here. I'm sleeping with Rita.
Oh Je -- couldn't he sleep with Rita? We'11 all have a good time.
I'm sorry.
Come on, let's go.
Where?
Somewhere.
They get in. They look at each other.
Do you want to go to a motel?
I feel like a criminal or, like we're cheating on someone.
(nicely) Just... just relax. Okay? We won't do anything. We'11 just sit here for a while.
Okay.
Come on...
Gently he puts his arm around her. At first, she hesitate but then curls up against him and relaxes.
I need to talk.
Are you all right?

She lied to me. I mean all my life, she's telling me one story and then... it turns out to be a completely different story. Come to me at some point -- tell me the truth. No. Not in my house. The truth is a stranger. And this is why Ray and Marcia are the way they are. Marcia gets involved with all these losers and sees no problem with herself - "How do they find me" she says. Ray cheats on you and then blames me for it. I'm the only one in the family who takes any responsibility for himself... Oh, man... Are you all right?
(hesitantly) Yeah... I saw that girl come on to you at the TV show.
Oh that was... no, I ... she just kind of trapped me into giving her a ride. It's you. I want you.
...yeah?

He TOUCHES her. They KISS. Then again. Their hands are roaming. They're hot. They're breathing hard. He's unbuttoning her blouse. Their hands are all over each oth Her blouse comes off. LIGHTS GO ON. They see cameras, shooting at them. Shari SCREAMS and covers her breasts.
Good morning. Welcome to another day of Ed TV. Last night, while most of us were asleep ... this happened.
FOUR GUYS in a disgustingly messy room, watching the repl Ed and Shari.
Yes!!
They GYRATE LEWDLY.
Shari is working. Ed is following her around. Shari is AN The cameras are there.
Get them away from me.
She takes PACKAGES OUT OF the TRUCK and THROWS them at th cameramen.
It's not their fault.
No. It's your fault.
She throws a package at him.
What do you want me to do? You want me to quit the show?!
No... Could you?
No. If I quit I don't get the balloon payment.
The what?
Ray borrowed this whole tub of money against this balloon payment that I don't get if I qu -- it's too complicated. I -- Besides...
What?
Pause.
You see how people look at me. Like when they ask for my autograph or say "Hi" to me... It's like I'm a basketball player or a... you know, like I'm someone.
Everybody's someone.

Well, yeah, everybody's someone. But I mean someone they want to be. I mean let's face it, I'm working in the video store, no one's coming in saying "oh, I wish I was that guy. 1 wish was rewinding that huge pile of tapes." At least for a month I'm not just a guy with a name tag. I'm famous.
A GUY YELLS from across the street.
Shari! Nice nipples.
And so are you.
GUYS keep YELLING "Shari!" She tries to go after them. Ed holds her back.
I don't want to be famous for getting caught with my shirt off. If I'm going to be famous --
The camera is right in her face. She grabs it.
(to the camera person) This is going right up your ass.
Come on.
He returns the camera. Shari starts for her truck.
Look... maybe we just better put us on hold until this is over.
She gets in her truck.
Come on! Loosen up. (trying to joke) See -- this is why seventy-one per cent of the people don't like you.
She SLAMS the TRUCK DOOR.
It was a joke! A... vicious, thoughtless stupid joke.
He bangs himself in the head. She drives away. He BOWS.
(to the camera) And that, for you kids out there, is how you screw up a relationship.
Ed enters. He's worn out. He plops down, and puts on the
(to the camera) I'm gonna watch anything but me.
Ed is flipping stations. Something makes him stop.
Coming in two weeks to the Lifestyle Channel -- Joma. His Dad's a cop, his brother's a bouncer in a topless bar, his sister is a black-belt social worker -- and Joma's living with two gals.
We see JOMA. He has a lot of charisma. He seems a little dangerous, but in an exciting way.
Hey, Ed! I'm coming to get you, man! I'm gonna eat you right up! (makes gobbling-up noises)
Watching. He's stunned.
They're watching a tape of Ed TV. Ed has just entered his apartment. A WOMAN is there, sitting on his sofa. She's caressing Ed's undershorts against her cheek. Ed is highl agitated.
How did you get into my apartment?!
The BODYGUARD is pulling her out. REVEAL that Scharlach, McIlvaine, Seaver, Cynthia and Gre all watching. McILVAINE What is she holding?
(calmly) A pair of Ed's underwear. McILVAINE Oh my God!
ON the TAPE, the woman while being forcibly evicted, offe the underwear to Ed. Ed recoils.
No -- keep it.
I love you! 1 want to marry you!
She's hauled out. They stop the tape.
See -- that's television! This other thing, this Jama, that has "stink" written all over it.
The break-up with Shari was very big. Big ratings.
Only, Cynthia, seriously. Tell Ed not to sneak out anymore.
Cynthia ...
He wants it accomplished.
It's in violation of his contract and if we wanted to be hard-nosed about it, he could forfeit all pay, including money he's already received.
(dutifully, but a tad resentfully) I will see that he's properly threatened.
Now what? What's on the young man's agenda? We don't want to see him sitting around like a lovesick puppy.
Young males do not want to see Ed get back with Shari.
(impatiently) Enough with her. That sailed. McILVAINE Could Ed live with two girls?
You know who the audience is requesting a lot? That girl, Jill, that Ed met at the Letterman show. She really scored.
Cynthia...
He wants it accomplished.
Ed is walking from his car to a building. CROWDS are behi barricades. They YELL at Ed as he passes. Ed is used to t
Rita OPENS the door and sees Ed.
(nervously) Oh. Ed.
Hi. Is Shari here?
No.
What is she, at work?
She left.
Well, when will she be back?
She won't.
What are you talking about?

She left. She moved. She got Fed-Ex to give her a transfer and she left. She couldn't stand it anymore. We had people, news people, regular people, just sleeping in our hallway, going through our mail, our garbage. I mean it was she couldn't take it anymore. Now I've got to move. I can't afford this place by myself.
I'm sorry. Where'd they send her?
She wouldn't tell me.
He's off the air. He's a little down. He's ON the PHONE-
She's working out an a contraption.
Remember when you were interviewing me? (details to follow)
Yeah.
You asked me if I had a dream. I said "Sure, I have a dream. I just don't know what it is yet."
Great line.
What if Shari's the dream?
Ed, do you want my advice?
Yeah, that's why I called. I mean, maybe Fed-Ex would tell me where she moved --
Leave her be.
You said a woman likes to be pursued.

Pursued, not harassed. Give it some space. Can I tell you something -- as a friend? My sister was going with a guy they hit a little rough spot they started seeing other people they got back together and last month they had their third child For what it's worth.
OPEN ON ANDY, Ed's half-Asian nephew. He's eight. He's wearing a baseball glove.
Throw me a high one, Uncle Eddie.
Okay.
REVEAL ED, also wearing a baseball glove. He throws a hig up to Andy. Andy staggers around and almost catches it.
Oh!!
We have to stop meeting like this.
Hm?
REVEAL JILL, walking a DOG. it takes just a second to recognize her.
Oh, hi.
Ed is hit with the ball.
Sorry.
REVEAL the Real TV Staff watching this on television in t office. As Ed and Jill chat in the background.
(to Cynthia) Did you arrange this?
(points to the TV) Whose dog is that?
(surprised) That's your dog.
Cynthia doesn't even smile.

1. Ed and Jill going into a chic club -- ushered in immediately. Here, as in the other times we see her, Jill comfortable with the situation. She's the opposite of Sha She poses willingly. She chats easily with paparazzi. She clings to Ed. There's nothing overt or obnoxious about he She's just comfortable and good at it and always looks gr 2. INTERVIEW with the guys who didn't like Shari.
Way to go, Ed!
Now, we're talking!
3. A N.Y. Post story: "Readers Pick Jill over Shari." Pictures of both women. Jill looks great. Shari is in her uniform and looks like a mouse.

In a new apartment. Watching Ed and Jill on TV. She's ver unhappy. She turns it off. 5. Ed and Jill at the nice restaurant he was at with Shar earlier. It looks like he's starting to like her. 6. Ed is refereeing a pro-wrestling match. He counts out villain who, then, jumps up and chases him out of the rin
Ed and Jill are in a HEAVY LIPLOCK. Carlos is right there the camera. Unlike Shari, Jill seems unself-conscious. Sh getting Ed pretty turned-on. SHOTS of VIEWERS, also turned on, especially the men.
You want to?
It's clear what she means. Ed is conflicted. He's clearly aroused.
Um... It's kind of ...
He looks for his watch on the wrong wrist, then seems to all around his body until he discovers it.
Are you busy tomorrow night?
No.
Why don't you come over. And I'11 make dinner. And you bring a movie. And ... We'11 make a night of it ... okay?
(nervously) Sure.
Written on the screen -- "Day 48" Ed is walking, the camera following. He looks tense. Peop SHOUT "Hey, Ed" "Ed-die" etc.
The New York Post front page -- "Is tonight the Night?" w picture of Ed and Jill kissing.
Oh man...
Hey, Eddie.
Ed looks up.
(giving the "thumbs up") Go for it!
Ed continues down the street. People YELL to him "Good lu tonight," "We're rooting for you" etc. A STREET CHARACTER walks alongside for a minute.
Hey, man. This is Haitian Love Juice. (he produces a vial) You give her this, she be yours.
Security grabs him and the vial falls and breaks. The liq hits the pavement and smokes up.
(looking at the smoke) Jesus!
More shouts "Be gentle", "We'11 be watching", "Use a cond A SCHOOL BUS passes. The KIDS YELL out the window to Ed.
(in unison) Good luck!
There is no line. At TICKET TAKER sits, bored. No one is going in or coming out.
It's deserted.
It's empty. The HEADWAITER stands in the doorway with not to do.
